description: From Middle English brinie, burne (whence also, without metathesis, obsolete English brinie), from Old Norse brynja. Cognates include Old English byrne, Gothic 𐌱𐍂𐌿𐌽𐌾𐍉 (brunjō) (whence Old Church Slavonic брънѩ (brŭnję)), German Brünne, French broigne.

entries.meaning: (historical) A short chain mail shirt, covering from the upper arms to the upper thighs.
examples: Unferth stood beside him, his huge arms folded on his byrnie.
